summary.p: 84 fol.; Writing surface: paper; Shelfmark: E. H. 109; Qurʾānic Text: unclear; 31 lines per page; Dimensions: 97 x 140mm; Script style: nasḫ.

This entry is based on the catalogue of Fehmi E. Karatay (1888-1968). Currently we do not have access to the images. With exceptions, the catalogue does not contain precise information on the distribution of the text throughout the pages. For this reason, only fol. 1 is given.

Karatay (1962) describes the manuscripts as follows, p. 28f: "87 E. H. 109. Aynı. Aharlı esmer kâğıt. 140mm boy ve 97mm eninde 84 yaprak. Sahifede harekeli ince arap neshli ile 62mm uzunl.[uğunda] 31 satır. Sonunda katabahu Abū Ḥanīfat an - Nu man .. suretinde bir yazı var ise de ondan sonra gelen kelimeler okunamıyor. Bu ketebenin tahrip edilerek bu şekle sokulduğuna şüphe yoktur. Yazı ve tezhip itibarı ile VI-VII (XII-XIII) asır işi olması muhtemeldir. Y. 1a da müzehhep müstatil levha, serlevha ve sure başları ve güller ayni üslûpta müzehhep. Durak işaretleri yoktur. Cetveller mavi ile. Miklepli deri cildin üzeri kumaşla kaplıdır."

This can be translated as follows: "87 E. H. 109. Same. Sized brown paper. 84 leaves of 140 mm height and 97 mm width. The text area written in fine Arabic naskh script with diacritics, [contains] 31 lines measuring 62 mm height. Towards the end, there is a writing in the form of “katabahū Abū Ḥanīfat al-Nuʿmān,” but the following words are unreadable. There is no doubt that this certificate of audition has been damaged. Based on the style of script and illumination, it is likely from the 6th-7th (12th-13th) centuries. [Leaf] L. 1a contains an illuminated plate in size of a whole page. Serlevha, sūra beginnings, and roses are decorated in the same style. There are no verse seperators. Rule-borders are in blue. The leather binding with flap (miklep) is covered with fabric.”
